items.q: Which European explorer famously led the first expedition that successfully circumnavigated the globe, although he died en route?
items.explanation: The expedition started in 1519, and completed the journey in 1522 under Juan Sebastián Elcano.

items.q: The defenestration of Prague in 1618 helped trigger the English Civil War.
items.explanation: It triggered the Thirty Years' War in Central Europe.

items.q: The famous Rosetta Stone was vital for deciphering ancient Egyptian hieroglyphs because it contained text in three different scripts.
items.explanation: It contained Hieroglyphic, Demotic, and Ancient Greek.

items.q: What conflict between Great Britain and China in the 19th century was fought over trade imbalances and the importation of narcotics?
items.explanation: It resulted in China ceding Hong Kong to Britain.

items.q: Who was the Soviet architect of 'Glasnost' and 'Perestroika' ending the Cold War?
items.explanation: His reforms unintentionally led to the dissolution of the Soviet Union.

items.q: What massive pre-Columbian city in Mesoamerica is known for its Pyramid of the Sun and Avenue of the Dead?
items.explanation: It was already in ruins by the time of the Aztecs.

items.q: What was the radical Jacobin period during the French Revolution, characterized by mass executions, called?
items.explanation: Robespierre was its most prominent leading figure.

items.q: What empire, centered in modern-day Cambodia, built the massive temple complex of Angkor Wat in the 12th century?
items.explanation: It was originally built as a Hindu temple and later transformed into a Buddhist site.

items.q: What series of 20th-century trials prosecuted prominent members of the political and military leadership of Nazi Germany?
items.explanation: It was a landmark event in international criminal law.

items.q: What was the name of the violent anti-Semitic pogrom across Nazi Germany on November 9-10, 1938?
items.explanation: SA paramilitaries and civilians destroyed Jewish businesses, homes, and synagogues.
